results.title: The McGillivray Family
results.brief_description: The story of the McGillivrays takes place in Gunbower on Saturday morning at the Gunbower Football Complex. This is a portrait of a family that has always worked the land, either as farmers or sheep shearers. They share their love of sports and concerns about the effects of the drought on small regional towns. All with a sense of humour and a never give up attitude that families need to survive in the current climate.

results.title: Gunbower: Family Albums
results.brief_description: This film features life long residents of Gunbower and their family connections to three historically rich properties. From Greg Toll’s ancestral home in Kow Swamp to the Old Butter Factory in the heart of the town to Masters Landing on the shores of the Murray River. Each location resonates with childhood memories of times past.

results.title: Colbo Nights
results.brief_description: Football practice, barbequed snags and a couple of beers at the pub. This is Thursday night in Colbinabbin and you can meet local characters such as Slab, Meathead and Stewballs. The atmosphere is one of a close knit community that loves sports, live music and supports each other through good times and bad.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Maffra
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Vox pops with the locals of Maffra. The township of Maffra in the Wellington Shire, southeast of Victoria, is home to approximately 4000 people and was chosen to host the third annual Small Towns Summit from 26 to 27 August 2009. The summit is an initiative of the Small Towns Victoria Program funded by Regional Development Victoria, organised by the Municipal Association of Victoria. The program aims to broadly address the issues facing small rural towns in Victoria.

Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra

results.title: Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra
results.brief_description:
This film focuses on the young people of Maffra. Eight students from Maffra Secondary College were interviewed, representing all the year levels, and asked to talk about life in a regional town, their hopes for the future and issues that affect them and their world.
The end result is a portrait of young rural Victorians who are thoughtful and engaging, with concerns about the environment, world politics and the survival of small towns.

results.title: Welcome to Maffra
results.brief_description: This film starts with Darren McCubbin, the Mayor of the Wellington Shire, welcoming the audience to Maffra. Darren explains that we are about to visit some of the places and meet some of the people that make Maffra a unique place to live. The film features the Geoff Webster Centre, the Gippsland Vehicle Collection, the Maffra Gymnastics Club, the George Gray Centre, Wallaby Rise Restaurant, Cambrai Backpacker Hostel and Jenny McDavitt an Alpaca farmer and Ferial Zikerman who is now internationally known for her Maffra Cheese.

Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra

results.title: The Milky way = Dairy farming in Maffra
results.brief_description: This film showcases farming in the Maffra region and features six farmers who are leading the way in innovation and new farming technologies. Alan Clyne and his son Allister together with Robert White and John White are involved in the Herd Improvement initiative. Graeme Anderson and his son Ross are making the most of new irrigation techniques. Max Warren introduces his Robotic Dairy, the first ever to be used in Australia.

results.title: 100 Years of Victorian women's right to vote
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Australian women have long been at the forefront of political change and civic reform. Over the decades, women have fought for their beliefs; the right to vote, professional advancement; and equality under the law. Watch the inspirational stories of eight women who were all first in their respective fields in this biographical documentary project. Produced by ACMI in partnership with the Victorian Government, through the Office of Women’s Policy Department of Planning and Community Development as part of the 2008 Celebration of the Centenary of Women’s Vote.

results.title: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis is the current Chair for the Federation of Ethnic Communities’ Councils of Australia (FECCA) an Honour Roll inductee and Member of the Order of Australia (AM). She co-founded the Victorian Immigrant and Refugee Women’s Coalition (VIRWC) and has served as Chair of the Immigrant Women’s Domestic Violence Service, as Inaugural Chair of the Women in the North Service, as Council member at the RMIT University, as well as on a number of State and Federal advisory and policy structures.
results.description: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis is the current Chair for the Federation of Ethnic Communities’ Councils of Australia (FECCA) an Honour Roll inductee and Member of the Order of Australia (AM). results.title: Lecki Ord
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Lecki Ord has an extensive career of community involvement and town planning and is a veteran campaigner for sustainable living. She has long been leading the way for women entering fields dominated predominantly by men since starting out as an architect in the 1960s. In 1987 Ord became the first female Lord Mayor of Melbourne and in 1995 became a founding member of the Women’s Planning Network.
